title: Will the average price of a gallon of gasoline fall below $1.95 for any week before 2 March 2021?
preds: Will the senate pass the 1.9 trillion usd bill?
The lowest National Prices were 10 months ago, as COVID caused a huge supply of gas.  The US continues to trend upward with the COVID vaccine rollout, and the fallout from Texas storms.

As previously stated, the combination of Biden administration policies combined with increased consumer travel as the virus wanes and the economy opens up will raise gas prices.  The rolling blackouts in Texas has recently placed further stress on gas prices with the temporary shutdown of their refineries.  Gas prices are rising fast.
Updating forecast as the time grows nearer.
With the recent energy crisis in Texas, I cannot see this happening anytime soon.
Oil companies will start price slashing to help rally their share prices
It came close but now the economy will start picking up as vaccine roll out continues and COVID seems to be on the decline, plus the stimulus package will add another shot in the arm for the economy.
General consensus puts current prices at around $2.50 nationwide, no way it will fall by 60 cents or more in one week.
Gas prices are far too high and the deadline is too close.

The current average price of gas is about $2.50 and with less than 2 weeks left until March 2nd, it is highly unlikely for the price to fall below $1.95. Also, with Biden's executive order blocking the Keystone XL Pipeline, it's highly unlikely to reach that price. I'm giving it a 2% chance because there is some time left for an event that will decrease gas prices to occur, but it's unlikely.

Gas prices will not fall because of Biden's executive order to stop the Keystone XL Pipeline and the new restrictions on drilling. The Biden administration has no current interest in lifting sanctions with Iran so prices aren't going down anytime soon.

The price of gas continues to rise with the price at $2.588 for the week of February 15th.  With cold weather slamming the country, prices are bound to remain at this level or increase over the next few weeks.
Gas prices are high and have been increasing

Gas prices swooned with uncertainty about demand during the initial onset of of the pandemic. There is now much more data on consumption levels, and a >20% drop in national gas prices is extremely unlikely.

In the couple weeks left before March 2, it is highly unlikely that gas prices will drop below $1.95 from the current average of $2.50, especially when prices have thus far been rising in recent weeks and months.
The price is going up steadily but there is still time for something crazy to happen.  https://www.eia.gov/dnav/pet/hist/LeafHandler.ashx?n=pet&s=emm_epm0_pte_nus_dpg&f=w
The new presidential election along with the Keystone project being canceled makes this highly unlikely
Since November gas prices have been on an upward trend starting at the lowest of $2.02, so it is highly unlikely it will drop below $1.95.
Gas prices have been on the uptick since the presidential election
There is a consensus of other forecasters since a lot of weeks

Updating for the passage of time - exceedingly unlikely. At this point we would need to see a rapid drop on a similar scale to what we saw early in covid - and as that took place over the course of a few weeks, we'd likely need to be seeing signs something was starting by now for the price to dip below $1.95.

With the new presidential administration, coupled with the cancellation of the keystone pipeline and the already inflated price of gasoline, it is impossible for the price of gasoline to fall below $1.95 in any time, likely before the summer or even autumn seasons. Also, the general trend of the gasoline prices has been trending upwards, the average was never lower than $2, and with the state of the government of the United States, it is impossible for the price of gas to reach a record low, or for the average to even decrease by a substantial amount.
It will not fall this low

the price has been trending up for the last 10 months.  The low point 10 months ago was 2.022, still above the target of this question.  https://www.eia.gov/dnav/pet/hist/LeafHandler.ashx?n=PET&s=EMM_EPM0_PTE_NUS_DPG&f=W
Gas prices are climbing with pipeline banned, and the average price of gas ($2.464) has been increasing for months now.

Gas prices continue to climb, likely based on increased economic activity as COVID cases decrease and as the Biden administration continues to act to ban pipelines and fracking on federal lands.  I expect gas prices to continue to increase at least through the summer travel season.

The average price of a gallon of gas for the week of Feb 1st is $2.495 and has been increasing every week since the end of November.  The chances of gas dropping $0.545 in less than four weeks is almost nonexistent.

EIA expects crude oil prices to stay above $50/barrel in 2021. [1]  "Oil futures declined on Friday [1/22], pulling U.S. prices lower for the week, after U.S. government data revealed an unexpected weekly rise in domestic crude supplies. A resurgence of COVID-19 infections in China and Southeast Asia also raised concerns about near-term oil demand." [2] This is a good example of how supply increased (inventories), and demand decreased (COVID resurgence), lowering oil futures and thus US prices.  However, I think that all parties involved in the oil market are very aware of the sensitivity of the situation and are monitoring it closely, so unless something catastrophic happens, it's highly unlikely that the US gas price falls below $1.95.  [1] https://www.eia.gov/todayinenergy/detail.php?id=46516
[2] https://www.marketwatch.com/story/oil-futures-sink-over-2-as-coronavirus-cases-flare-up-in-asia-europe-11611320717
Update for time remaining until end date

There is no reason to expect a drastic drop in average pricing from $2.44 today (29 Jan) to $1.95 before 2 March 2021.  Gas prices have remained fairly steady over the winter.  With the vaccine roll-out, I believe travel will increase, increasing demand, thus increasing pricing.
Updating as time passes. With Saudi Arabia cutting output and most OPEC+ countries maintaining steady production through February, the likelihood continues to shrink

The week this question opened has been its lowest rate to date, $2.194 per gallon.  Since then, the price has steadily climbed to its current price of $2.403 per gallon.  Gas prices would have to fall over $0.45 per gallon to drop below $1.95.     https://www.eia.gov/dnav/pet/hist/LeafHandler.ashx?n=pet&s=emm_epm0_pte_nus_dpg&f=w Additionally, EIA forecasts gasoline prices to average $2.40 per gallon in 2021. In the beginning of December, OPEC+ agreed to increase production rates by 500K barrels a day in January.  This act signals that OPEC+ countries believe oil price recovery will continue for the foreseeable future.   https://www.wsj.com/articles/opec-allies-near-agreement-for-small-production-increase-11606987819

As 2 March draws closer and gas prices continue to rise, it appears less and less likely that prices will drop below $1.95.  If anything, potential increased COVID lockdowns and Biden administration energy policies may drive the price of gasoline up further.
Yes, it is already close to those values.
Updating based on the passage of time. After the US inauguration and whatever fallout may or may not come out of that, I expect I'll be lowering significantly after feb 1

Updating based on time - there is little time and few surprises left to be had between now and march and it would take a significant surprise or calamity to drop prices quickly that quickly; Covid is a relatively known quantity, unrest regarding the election is still (today in particular) running hot but the likelihood that substantially impacts gas prices is low.
Saudi Arabia agreed to production cuts to allow Russian and Kazakhstan to increase production to keep the peace and stabilize the market.  Crude prices are the highest since February 2020.

Method 1
Looking from 2011 - 2020, I counted 10 weeks (2016 - 6 weeks, 2020 - 4 weeks) where the value of gasoline fell below $1.95.
With there 8 weeks before 2/3/2021 ->
Value1 = 15% = 8 * (10 / (52 * 10)) Method 2
With there typically a number of years gap between x<$1.95 (2005, 2009, 2016, 2020) ->
Value2 = 5% Value = 10% = (Value1 + Value2) / 2

The only time since the start of the pandemic that the average price of gasoline has dropped below $2.00 per gallon was in April 20 during the height of the lockdowns.  Since then, many states have decided to ease lockdown policies and Americans are largely resuming at least some level of commuting and leisure activities.  Because gas has remained above $2.00 consistently since then, it seems unlikely that the price would fall again below $1.95 in the next two months.
I favor a <1% chance, but GJOpen will not allow float values...

2020-Dec 12/07 $2.246 12/14 $2.247 12/21 $2.311 2/28 	$2.330
Notice that the price is increasing.

It would take a lot to drop the price from current levels. And consumption will only increase as the vaccine provides confidence and people become more mobile.
2020-Dec	12/07 	$2.246   	12/14 	$2.247   	12/21 	$2.311
Looks unlikely, but there's always the possibility of some kind of shock or change to the oil markets that could drive it down temporarily. The timeframe of the question is short though.
If anything, the price should probably inch upwards through New Year's.  I just don't see a circumstance that would case a $0.30+ drop over a two month period.

Responses to the 2019 novel coronavirus disease (COVID-19) continue to affect transportation—and by extension, fuel demand—in the United States, particularly for aviation. For the week of Thanksgiving 2020, total U.S. consumption of major petroleum transportation fuels (motor gasoline, distillate, and jet fuel), for which the U.S. Energy Information Administration (EIA) uses product supplied as a proxy, was down 1.7 million barrels per day (b/d) (11%) relative to Thanksgiving week 2019. Jet fuel accounted for about half of this decline. Jet fuel’s relatively large role in the decline of overall U.S. transportation fuel consumption is particularly noteworthy given that it has the smallest share of the three major transportation fuels used in the United States. Jet fuel consumption averaged 1.8 million b/d in 2019 compared with 9.3 million b/d for gasoline and 4.0 million b/d for distillate.

Gas prices continuing to rise, stimulus checks with direct payments becoming more likely (will further spur economy), and COVID vaccine distribution further increase my confidence in this forecast.  All info from my previous forecast remain constant.
OPEC is doing its best to prevent this from happening

The overall price seems to have only dropped below $2.00 per gallon twice in the last ten years: Feb-March 2016 and Apr 2020. I agree with the consensus that it is not likely to happen in the next few months unless another unexpected catastrophe were to happen. https://www.eia.gov/dnav/pet/hist/LeafHandler.ashx?n=PET&s=EMM_EPM0_PTE_NUS_DPG&f=W

NO federal lockdown and increasing tensions with Iran will keep gas above $1.95 for this time period. Only Federal lockdown and or massive layoffs like during the great recession will push below this number.

As COVID cases continue to rise, lockdowns solidify, and winter takes old gas prices are likely to fall. Last February before the pandemic gas prices bottomed to a seasonal low of 2.52. As the April lockdowns set in the price plummeted to 1.87. However, I believe with gas prices remaining steady over the early winter ~2.20 there is no reason to belief prices will fall due to demand by 25 cents. Regional tensions in the Middle East may also provide support for the price despite decreasing demand. Adjusting forecast downward.

The price tracked in the EIA has not reached that level in March since 2016. It was not at that level in March 2020 just before the US hit lockdowns.
OPEC+ has demonstrated that they can throttle their output to maintain price stability. Indeed gas prices have been stable from last July thru December.
US frackers are licking their wounds and conserving cash if they have any and won't be drilling anytime soon. So demand will be tepid and supply will be ample and controlled, so stability should rein thru at least May 2021.
If the incoming Biden administration pursues it's efforts to limit fracking, gas prices will rise, not fall.

A few interesting aspect of the seasonality of fuel/gasoline prices, besides "driving season" in summer, which I came across here:
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gasoline#United_States_3 /The influence of taxes on average retail prices
"In the United States, most consumer goods bear pre-tax prices, but gasoline prices are posted with taxes included. Taxes are added by federal, state, and local governments. As of 2009, the federal tax is 18.4¢ per gallon for gasoline and 24.4¢ per gallon for diesel (excluding red diesel). Among individual states, the highest gasoline tax rates, including the federal taxes as of October 2018, are found in Pennsylvania (77.1¢/gal), California (73.93¢/gal), and Washington (67.8¢/gal)." Taxes are not only a way of generating revenues and cash flow for the state and federal budget, but also a way of influencing behavior ("nudging"), pricing negative externalities ("external cost", e.g. air pollution), changes in taxes are therefore a steering instrument to stimulate (lower taxes) or crowd out (raise taxes) demand for certain products, one of which gasoline is due to its high potential as an air pollutant. Thus, 
(i) it appears likely with a new federal government coming and a renewed focus on environment protection that the federal taxes on gasoline will not fall in absolute terms, and may even rise relative to production cost, transport and other lumps and their respective shares in the final retail price. As the retail price (as stated in the quote above) of the EIA statistics apparently contains taxes, these will have an increasing influence on the price per gallon for the remainder of this question and will prevent the retail gasonline prices to fall significantly, even if demand slows and/or crude oil markets see a price slump (barred a total collapse of the world oil market, once more).
(ii) To the contrary, states with a traditional focus on environment protection, such as CA, states with a distressed budget, or states with certain issues caused by transportation may use tax raises on fuels in times of low fuel prices (~2.00 USD) to come up for increased spending without causing a major economic footprint or slowdown. Election year is almost over, so a rise in fuel taxation may be one of the first impertinences and hardships which politics may agree on without fear of the voter's rage.
Both federal and state taxes therefore have a smoothing, stabilizing effect on retail gasoline prices and also appear to put a "floor" price to it. A tax raise is even more likely during winter, as the seasonality of retail prices suggest falling prices: due to being "off-driving-season", but also because of the cheaper "winter-grade fuel":
/"Summer-grade fuel" vs. "Winter-grade fuel", and "transition season"
As the name of the EIA's source "Weekly U.S. All Grades All Formulations Retail Gasoline Prices" suggests, fuels vary with respect to grade and formulation.
https://web.archive.org/web/20150530115419/http://auto.howstuffworks.com/fuel-efficiency/fuel-consumption/summer-fuel.htm
Because of a differing blend, different additives and different minimum requirements in Reid Vapor Pressure (RVP)," up to 20 different types of boutique fuel blends are sold throughout the U.S. during the summer", which tend to have a higher retail price due to more costly ingredients, an increased demand during driving season, and due to temporary refinery shutdown in the "transition period" (March to May) from winter-grade fuel to summer-grade fuel.
("Depending on the part of the country, the EPA's standards mandate an RVP below 9.0 PSI or 7.8 PSI for summer-grade fuel. Some local regulations call for stricter standards. Because of these varying RVP standards, up to 20 different types of boutique fuel blends are sold throughout the U.S. during the summer."
https://web.archive.org/web/20150530161621/http://auto.howstuffworks.com/fuel-efficiency/fuel-consumption/summer-fuel1.htm )
https://web.archive.org/web/20150530210718/http://www.epa.gov/otaq/regs/fuels/r01051.pdf As the question started on 17 November 2020 and ends on 02 March 2021 at the latest, it spares any transition season:
The summer-to-winter transition begins in September already and is supposed to be completed already, as the main goal of the EPA's reformulation requirements was the prevention of toxic SMOG in metropolitan areas during summer.
The next transition, winter-to-summer, will not begin before March/April 2021.
Thus, there are no big erroneous jumps to be expected until 02 March 2021 due to a transition.
However, the "transition season" and the difference between "winter-grade fuel" and "summer-grade fuel" can provide an explanation and outlook crucial to the resolution of this question.
The source offers the following trough of retail fuel prices in 2020 so far:
  2020-Mar     03/16  	2.343    	03/23  	2.217    	03/30  	2.103   
  2020-Apr 	04/06  	2.022    	04/13  	1.951    	04/20  	1.910    	04/27  	1.870    	  	   
  2020-May 	05/04  	1.883    	05/11  	1.941    	05/18  	1.969    	05/25  	2.049    	  	   
  2020-Jun 	06/01  	2.064    	06/08  	2.123  Average prices of less than1.95USD were recorded only in the four weeks between 14 April 2020 and 10 May 2020 (as reported on 20/27 April; 04/11 May 2020).
In the light of the "transition problem", I interpret the trough as follows:
(i) "winter-grade" gasoline retail prices do not necessarily have to be low, or below 2.00USD, as the first three weeks of March 2020 (03/02: 2.514  -  03/09: 2.468   -  03/16: 2.343) show. Even in the five months of winter 2019/20 before, which probably are the classical "winter-grade fuel season", the retail gasoline price always averaged between 2.511USD and 2.742USD. The "2019 Abqaiq–Khurais attack" had happened on 14 September 2019, causing strong oil market disruptions for the second half of September 2019.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2019_Abqaiq%E2%80%93Khurais_attack
https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/a/a3/Brent_crude_oil_futures_prices%2C_August_2019_through_January_2020_%2849467835818%29.png
Especially for October and November 2019, the Weekly U.S. All Grades All Formulations Retail Gasoline Prices proved to be remarkably resilient to falling oil prices, and only after the military strike killing the Iranian general Soleimani on 02 January 2020, even retail gas prices joined the crude oil price in a prolonged decline.
From this, one could extract some kind of "political risk/uncertainty premium" of about 10 to 12% or 25 to 30 USc per gallon, about the reaction of the US and their allies to the "2019 Abqaiq–Khurais attack".
The Iranian retaliation has thus far not happened, but times (election result, transition of power-period to the new US administration) are pretty much still the same uncertain, and things could get worse still. Starting from the most recent price at 2.211USD, we could observe a risk premium added of 0.15 to 0.30USD per gallon, which could very well persist throughout the next months, which would drive the retail gas prices to about 2.35 to 2.50USD c.p. .
(ii) I assume the price collapse of March to April 2020 is a more or less unique coincidence of failure from different parties, which is unlikely to repeat in that magnitude.
a) first, the 45 POTUS administration lacked knowledge, competence to analyze and probably intelligence about the true potential impact of SARS-CoV-2 on the global and domestic economy and the requirement to put in place a future strict mandate (from the public health perspective) as late as January and the beginning of February 2020. Instead, they chose to repeat China's conciliations, probably to avoid putting at risk the Chinese - U.S. trade and tariff negotiations to end the economic war between ChiMerica.
b) When the 45 POTUS administration had received the intelligence and knew about the potential fall out, which according to the "Woddward tapes" happened in mid February 2020 at the latest, the administration failed to communicate a clear-cut response and explicit advisory to actors of the economy during following months. While some individuals of the administration still believed the virus would "magically disappear" ("no impact on the economy or demand" hypothesis), those voices who demanded an early enforced physical distancing, curfew and economic shut down included, were either silenced or undercut by a wall of noise and mixed messaging. The administration chose to cover up the expected impact, probably due to a major conflict of interest inherent in the facts that 45 POTUS is a "business owner" (Trump organization) himself, and that 2020 as an election year is especially sensitive with respect to unemployment rate, GDP growth, stock market performance (401k accounts). While the president advocated a "full throttle economic activities" response ("Reopen the economy!" "Reopen schools!" "Reopen houses of worship!" "Liberate Michigan!" and so on...) and pressured governors to end state mandates, even republican governors had to follow the logic of "flattening the curve", and, as a result, the U.S. had neither a strategy nor stringent communication nor a population educated enough to protect themselves.
Amid this mixed messaging and downplaying, which lasted at least until the infamous "total authority" press conference on 13 April 2020,
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=r3QXrQDTDYo
c) decision makers in the economy, in our case in the oil and refining industry, were likely blindfolded for weeks and month, likely for the entire spring, and due to the WH administration's
false claims
false data/falsified data
incomplete data (e.g. testing volume and case confirmation)
incomplete information made erroneous and wrong forecasts and predictions about the 2020 fuel demand, and, this is my key point, about the demand for the remainder of the 2020 "winter-grade fuel" season, which is likely not marketable during summer, even under pandemic conditions.
d) based on wrong demand projections, the oil industry reacted late in reducing capacity in production or purchase of crude oil. As the whole process of reducing capacity requires preparation and (I would guess) at least two to four weeks of time, and the entire industry was hit by the widespread shut down in April by surprise (45 POTUS promised everybody it would not happen; the governors of both sides of the aisle found out it was inevitable), my assumption is that the refineries will have produced more than ample amounts of "winter-grade fuel" and they failed to adapt on short notice. Even if the oil industry had lowered capacity in e.g. refineries quicker, there would have been backlogs of crude or products in other places. The oil industry, it seems, is especially vulnerable to market impairments, and by and large depends on a swift, smooth and frictionless production and delivery more than other industries.
d) As a consequence, from March 2020 the daily production of "winter-grade fuel" must have exceeded demand largely while exporting product could not offer relief: the global reduction in economic activity (and thus energy consumption) happened synchronously and the situation with an excess supply was similar in most G20 nations. As a consequence, storage and tankers were filled, however, they were unfortunately filled with "winter-grade gasoline", as the disruption happened *before* the transition season in refineries.
e) During mandatory shut downs and even after these had ended, gasoline producers were likely forced to dump their inventory of "winter-grade gasoline" to the domestic market via the gasoline retailers at any price to rid themselves of it ahead of the April/May "transition season", and to free storage. That way, the average retail gasoline price came under pressure from a combination of differing parties, relations, practical constraints and timing coincidence, which likely is the main reason behind the sharp and prolonged drop in average prices between, say, 17 March and 18 May 2020. As mentioned before, I suggest it is very very unlikely, that this "once-in-a-century"-constellation of factors, which caused a drop of 0.08USD or 5% at maximum below the threshold of 1.95USD/gal, repeats, and if it does (maybe to a weaker extent), not only is there far more knowledge about this particular virus and an awareness of "pandemics" as a major threat to business in general, but the industries will have used the time over summer to increase preparedness, to elaborate detailed contingency planning, a "playbook" for market disruptions, and increase business continuity efforts and co-ordination with e.g. administrative bodies, banks, insurance companies etc. in order to safeguard a reliable production and supply, and avoid another widespread collapse.

Outside view: 
Since 2010: total # of weeks = 569, # of weeks under $1.95/gallon = 10 (5 in 2016, 5 in 2020). % of weeks under $1.95 = 1.76%. # of weeks until March 2 = 12. Odds that no weeks under $1.95 before March 2 = (100-1.76)% ^ 12 = 80.8%. So odds that we will have 1+ weeks under $1.95 before March 2 = 100 - 80.8 = 19.2%. That's my baseline. Inside view: 
What determines gas price? 1) Crude oil prices; 2) refining; 3) distribution and marketing; 4) taxes. [1] I don't see refining, distribution, marketing, or taxes dramatically changing between now and March. And about 55-60% of gas price is determined by crude oil price anyway.  What determines crude oil price? 1) Spot prices; 2) Supply OPEC; 3) Supply non-OPEC; 4) Balance; 5) Financial markets; 6) Demand OPEC; 7) Demand non-OPEC. All of this is taken into account in EIA's Short Term Economic Outlook (STEO) seen in the first slide here [3]. EIA actually forecasts that crude oil will slightly increase in 2021, although beginning of 2021 (scope of this question) appears to be flat. Market futures also appear to be flat through 2021. This leads me to lower from the 19% baseline. OPEC: Latest OPEC meeting said they would keep oil production stable for rest of 2020, and start increasing demand slowly in 2021 with "monthly meetings of oil ministers to reassess the balance of supply and demand." [4] It appears that OPEC will be monitoring this closely and adjust production accordingly so that prices don't drop too low. Also leads me to lower from my 19% baseline.  Forecast: so from the 19% outside view, I'll lower down to 14% given EIA forecast, market futures, and OPEC meeting. Will lower each week going forward.  [1] https://www.eia.gov/energyexplained/gasoline/factors-affecting-gasoline-prices.php
[2] https://www.eia.gov/finance/markets/crudeoil/
[3] https://www.eia.gov/outlooks/steo/#:~:text=Price%20Summary%20%20%20%20%20%20,%20%2013.22%20%204%20more%20rows%20
[4] https://www.npr.org/2020/12/03/938972926/opec-to-modestly-boost-output-ending-divisive-talks-amid-uncertain-global-econom

There have only been 3 months since March of 2009 that the average price has dipped below $2 per gallon, and one of those months was COVID related.  The other two months were in the winter/spring of 2016, which were the result of a massive two year drop in oil prices relating to a supply glut that was in no small part related to the boom in shale oil production (https://blogs.worldbank.org/developmenttalk/what-triggered-oil-price-plunge-2014-2016-and-why-it-failed-deliver-economic-impetus-eight-charts).  Driving prices below $1.95 takes significant and sustained market forces in one direction.  Even with a massive reduction in global oil demand during the COVID pandemic, prices have only dropped to this range for one month.  Labor Day and Thanksgiving holiday travel showed that Americans are willing to travel despite escalating infection numbers.  And with the release of a vaccine in western countries this month and strong domestic travel in China, there is little reason to anticipate a significant dip in the next three months.

Based on OPEC+ agreement, oil prices will remain relatively constant through January, with the agreement's short duration aimed at enabling the countries to adapt to situational contexts in order to maintain stability. Also, based on this occurring 33% of the time in 2020 and before COVID not since 2016.

Holding at 5%. Opec and Russia maintaining control to keep,prices from falling like they did this spring.  https://www.npr.org/2020/12/03/938972926/opec-to-modestly-boost-output-ending-divisive-talks-amid-uncertain-global-econom

Update: Previous forecast had an error in the bootstrapping procedure, so I deleted the associated comment. Bootstrapping by randomly sampling a single year to pick all of the past multiplicative increments in the price from gives a 5/27 = %18.5 chance that the price will fall below $1.95 before 2nd March 2021. In other words, 5 years out of 27 from 1993 to 2019 saw a consecutive sequence of percentage weekly changes in the price of gasoline starting from this time of the year that would bring the current price below $1.95 at some point before 2nd March 2021. This procedure takes into account both the seasonality effects on the price and most (though not all) of the autocorrelation in the increments. I think it's a good estimate of the base rate. In this case I find it difficult to justify an adjustment to the base rate in either direction, so I'll just use the base rate as my forecast after rounding down.
Dropping as i track pric e increases that are a result of tax increases.
OPEC will not have increased production, increasing supply but March 2021

Reduction by 18% -  very little has changed since my original forecast, but I've reviewed the historical patterns for WTI, Brent, and Opec and their relationship to US gas prices. I'm in agreement that, given business as usual, it is quite unlikely to drop below $1.95. Unlike April and May, Covid is a (relatively) known quantity now and likely doesn't have much in store regarding surprises. It would take not just a bad, but a cataclysmic holiday season (covid-wise) for the pandemic to drive the price down this far.  I'm not an optimist regarding Covid rates and hospital beds this winter, in fact, I think there are too many optimists when it comes to the winter (for us in the northern hemisphere) outlook for the pandemic. I'd say there's a ~15% chance of this winter being cataclysmic to the extent that gas prices drop below $1.95 leading to a massive reduction from my previous forecast.
I beleive that the influence of the pandemic in economy will disipates even in a second wave

Last time was in April, in the middle of maximum Covid-19 uncertainty and a knocked-down economy everwhere on the planet. https://www.eia.gov/dnav/pet/hist/LeafHandler.ashx?n=pet&s=emm_epm0_pte_nus_dpg&f=w

Sourcing for my previous assessment. https://www.eia.gov/outlooks/steo/#:~:text=Price%20Summary%20%20%20%20%20%20,%20%2013.22%20%204%20more%20rows%20 The alternative assessment is that COVID worsens through the end of 2020 and into early 2021 thus decreasing consumption further, driving oil production cuts and decreasing prices.  However, I expect the market to balance against global supply/demand and maintain the price.

As a baseline, oil prices are expected to go up from now until early 2021 (currently at $2.22).  Supply is going down due to lower production given domestic storms, COVID and attacks on foreign oil structures. Consumer demand is expected to go up during the 2020 holidays into what is presumed as an early 2021 COVID recovery.  Taxes and the balance of gas pricing will reflect these changes in crude price, supply and demand resulting in a slight increase, rather than a decreased average to $1.95.
WTI needs to fall below $20 for gas to fall below $2. That's very unlikely in next 3 months. Staying with my forecast.

There have been 5 covid weeks this year where the average was <$1.95. That gives us a base rate of somewhere around 1:6. There are roughly 13 weeks before this question closes. The weeks that this happened were all sequential. Now that we've been through this, it makes sense that companies would take steps to try and prevent prices from falling so much. The linked Newsweek article in fact mentions production caps that different companies have been considering (though notably these are opposed by bigger companies).

Looks like the gasoline price do not move at the same rate as WTI. In recent past, even a 15% correction in WTI has lead to only a 2-4% correction in gasoline price. Gas prices seem to be very stable at this point of time.

Prices have been low all year, there hasn't been travel all year, US oil companies are struggling, and no one wants prices to drop even more. Hard for me to imagine situations where prices get really low... Saudi isn't about to flood the market (Armaco is struggling for cash), Russia isn't in position to flood the market, US companies are going out of business. I have to imagine that low amounts of travel in the US for the holiday season is already semi-priced in.
With a Biden win, the trading with foreign countries will likely resume, as will the former prices.

The week of May 11th it rose to 1.94 and then rose the next week to over 2 dollars and it has not fallen to under 2 dollars since then. Last week it was 2.02. With covid rising and less cars on the road it may continue to fall a little. However, we also have good news on a vaccine. I would say the odds of it falling below 1.95 again by March 2nd are low but we also have to add in the chances it falls for some other reason such as a war oversees or oil spill. I will set it at 25% and come back every two weeks as we get new numbers.

As COVID cases/hospitalizations/deaths appear likely to exceed records, lockdowns/stay-at-home orders appear more likely at the local level which will drive gas prices lower as the economy downshifts to telework. With the economic impact likely to be greater than the initial surge as unemployment benefits run out, housing evictions resume en masse, and reductions in travel transitioning to long term problems gas prices can be expected to drop as they did in March/April of 2020.

Using initial base rate for this time period from 1994 tp 2020 using EIA price data

National gas prices currently average $2.115. Prices typically fall in the upcoming winter months - August is usually $0.35 higher than in January. Assuming half of this cyclic decrease has already occurred, $1.94 is the forecast winter low. Increasing COVID cases and looming lockdowns also threaten to depress prices further.
the current macro economic environment seems primed for growth despite COVID-19.

As COVID-19 cases spike across the U.S., many states are beginning to impose new restrictions on certain economic activity.  During the shutdown in the spring and the increase in people staying home, the ensuing reduced travel helped to drive gasoline prices as low as $1.87 for the week ending on 4/27.  This round of shutdowns, while perhaps smaller in scope, is occurring during the winter months, when gasoline prices are typically lower due to reduced travel.  The lack of widespread shutdowns will compete with the typically lower gasoline prices in the winter to produce a moderate possibility that the price falls below $1.95.
Gas is already at $2.12 a gallon and the government is warning of travel which could cause some folks who normally drive for the holidays to stay home.

This time around believe even as the case counts continues to mount we wont see the magnitude of shutdowns that we saw in early march. We also saw a Oil price war in early April which had an impact. probabilities of a repeat of that scenario seems remote as well. US Gasoline demand seems to be seasonally steady for now. 9% below 5 year average. 
Still keeping some room for unforseen shocks (Lifting of sanctions from Iran, Another disruption in global oil markets)

Gas prices appear to be on a downward trend but still well above $1.95 as the industry appears to be managing supply so I have low expectations for below $2 gas especially now that we are entering winter and demand for heating oil will soak up some refining capacity

Crude oil prices are forecast to stay in the $40/B range, but the EIA's short term forecast (released 11/10) shows a forecast of $1.89/gal in January. However the same chart shows average retail gasoline prices at $2.158 for October, which "all grades" value for this question ended the month at $2.234/gal. While a dip in retail price would be expected in the Dec-Jan time frame, will it be enough to get below $1.95/gal without ramped up production like we saw back in 2Q 2020? Probably not, but it is possible. https://www.eia.gov/outlooks/steo/report/prices.php

The current surge in coronavirus infections will force expanded returns to the lockdowns which drove away demand for fuel.  While there's a possibility that heating oil demand may surge, it is unlikely as the predictions are that climate change will make this a relatively mild winter.

Statewide/National Lockdowns or not, if there are limited places to go (bc of closures) or you don’t feel safe (bc high number of cases in the area) you aren’t going to travel. Plain & simple. New cases are rising exponentially & that means disruptions to gasoline demand are also rising exponentially.  Winter in US also provides significantly less appeal to distant drives, for outdoor events/activities, relative to late spring lockdowns. Potential exists for overwhelming healthcare system in areas, and this risk is rising as hospitalizations increase exponentially and recently reached new highs. This is promote fear and self-imposed restrictions... OPEC+ appears more amenable to agreement but without overt national shutdowns they are likely to fall behind the curve.

Initial forecast - at a glance, it appears in recent years that there has been a mostly regular a dip between november and march. If we assume that (admittedly rough) pattern holds, what is the probability that the dip will exceed 11.5% of the current level (2.202 as of this writing). We saw this in 2013-14, 2015-16, and 2018-19; 3 times in the last 10 years. That provides a 30% baseline. There is likely to be a spike in covid cases and a resulting spike in restrictions during and following the holidays, driving this up - it's difficult to quantify at this point, but I suspect the holidays will produce some devastating covid numbers (although, I would very much like to be wrong) which will impact no only travel but supply chains and the broader market. I have high confidence that the holidays will be particularly bad (I'd say 90% confidence) and pretty confident (we'll say 75%) that this will significantly impact the price of gasoline.  I'm not familiar with the politics or history outside of what is presented by the EIA graphs so for now, this leads me to adjust up to 48%, but will monitor

The table indicates the sub-$1.95 price drops during the pandemic (and in general to a lesser extent) have little to do with the health crisis and everything to do with the man-made, meteoric price drop in April 2020. My hunch is that things will have to get very bad for this to resolve "YES" organically.

The gas price in USA dropped below $1.95 for 49 days since the US declared a state of emergency which gives an initial benchmark of approximately 17% likely that the gas price will drop below the threshold. Drastic rises in cases of COVID 19 have had a far smaller impact on gas prices since the initial drop, this combined with the announcement of plausible vaccines see the likelihood come down further to approximatley 15. Christmas will bring it down further as passengers won't trust air travel, possibly 13. However, Biden's election win makes a lockdown more likely and asociated focus on green energy will see a move away from gas seeing a rise to 18%
The entire world economy will remain depressed by the pandemic through March.

It’s used as a tool for the economy. People are struggling and prices are going up on consumer products steadily because so many businesses have closed. It’s better to have more affordable fuel so people can travel to work and to shop.

The positive news about Pfizer’s coronavirus vaccine trial, and hopes that it and other vaccines could bring the pandemic under control, caused oil prices to soar, as investors bet that consumption will recover when consumers can travel freely again. Hopes for a COVID-19 vaccine recently sent benchmark West Texas Intermediate crude futures to $41 per barrel, up several dollars from the pre-Pfizer-news price.  The rally may continue in the near term, but we think prices will pull back again as traders realize that, no matter how effective any vaccine is, it’ll be months before one can be distributed widely enough to let life get back to normal. In the meantime, oil demand will likely remain depressed.  Kiplinger's latest forecast on the direction of energy prices By: Jim Patterson
November 10, 2020

Great question.  Gasoline is a refined product so refiners use crack spreads as a hedge.  So if world has cheap oil refiners are not going to react immediately to that since their production budgets and budgets are locked in.  If Crude prices crater today then gas moves 3 months later; hedging effect..  Demand for gasoline is inflated while coijd ravages the country since more people  choose to drive than fly.  Yse, we will have two vaccines being deployed but this is the the start of vaccinations so i do not see a change in transport choices.  Winter will also cooperate to keep construction moving since its a warmer winter forecast due to la nina.  Also the low price was april 2020 1.87. So overall i do not think prices will dip below 1.95 by march 2.

Of course, if it goes down that much, demand will be pushed up a bit by vast hordes of good patriotic amurricans running out to buy big ol' gas-sucking SUVs, overpowered watercraft and snowmobiles, and perfectly useless petrol-burners like leafblowers.  They will then demand gummint action when the price goes back up again.  Kinda makes you proud.

While gas prices have remained below $2 locally, it is because we have a low gas tax rate.  https://www.columbiamissourian.com/news/local/missouris-average-gas-prices-lowest-in-country/article_cd18cdaa-24f9-11eb-b46a-f7df79adee8f.html Companies are converting to fuel oil for the winter, which lends stability. Additionally, the drop this Spring was caused by more than simply less travel, several countries contributed to the drop by increasing production, leaving a glut.

Industry says they are shutting in low producers and delaying bringing new production line while continuing exploration. I'll watch for that to bring down my 100%. Otherwise I espect a bigger glut than last year.
